metadata.title: Integral method of preparation and fabrication of metal matrix composite: Selective laser melting of in-situ nano/submicro-sized carbides reinforced iron matrix composites

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Materials Science & Engineering A
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/msea
Integral method of preparation and fabrication of metal matrix composite: Selective laser melting of in-situ nano/submicro-sized carbides reinforced iron matrix composites
Bo Song⁎, Zhiwei Wang, Qian Yan, Yuanjie Zhang, Jinliang Zhang, Chao Cai, Qingsong Wei, Yusheng Shi State Key Laboratory of Materials Processing and Die &Mould Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Selective laser melting Cr3C2/Fe nanocomposites Carbides Tensile strength
A B S T R A C T
This paper presents a study on the formation, microstructure and mechanical property of Cr3C2/Fe nanocomposites using selective laser melting (SLM). Scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscope (TEM) and tensile tests were conducted to investigate the influence of Cr3C2 particulates on the microstructure and mechanical properties. It was found that the porosity decreased when volumetric energy density increased from 27 to 37 J/mm3, then rose to 55 J/mm3. The results showed that the Cr3C2 particulates decomposed completely during SLM process and interacted with Fe matrix to form (α-Fe, Cr) solid solution and M(Fe, Cr)23C6 carbides. In addition, due to the characteristic of rapid solidification, very fine grains were obtained throughout the composites. The tensile tests showed that the ultimate tensile strength could reach up to 1158 MPa.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Metal matrix composites (MMCs), with both the ductility and toughness of metals as well as high strength and stiffness of reinforced particles, have been applied in the machinery, automobile and aerospace industries in the past few decades. Especially, metal matrix nanocomposites have attracted increasing attention due to the dispersion of nanometer-sized secondary phases in the grain boundaries and grains, which in turn contribute to obtain better mechanical, chemical and physical properties [1–3]. Up to now, a wide range of MMCs with different reinforcements has been investigated, mainly including Tibased [4,5], Al-based [6,7], Fe-based [8,9], and Ni-based [10].
However, it is a challenge to retain the nanostructure of ceramic particulates in the final parts by traditional consolidation techniques such as hot pressing and hot isostatic pressing. Because the nano grains possessing large van der Waals and surface adsorption force will tend to agglomerate when subjected to high temperature for a long time, making it difficult to retain the grain size at nanometer scale [11]. On the other hand, it is also very difficult to implement the integral forming of components with complex structure via the majority of conventional processing routes [12,13]. Thus, it is necessary to seek a new processing technique for the integral forming of nanocomposite components with complex structure.
Selective laser melting (SLM), as an important member of additive manufacturing technologies, is a new manufacturing technology based on the method of accumulation in a layer-by-layer fashion. By directly melting the single layer of powder using a high-energy laser beam, the technology enable the rapid fabrication of MMC parts with complex structure. In addition, due to the characteristics of rapid solidification in micro molten pool, SLM technique can effectively avoid the nano ceramic agglomeration and grain growth [14,15].
So far, there have been some works devoted to the study of the SLMprocessed MMCs reinforced by common ceramic particulates, such as SiC, TiC, TiB2 and hydroxyapatite [2,13,16]. Among these studies, a considerable part is on the preparation of Ti-based and Al-based composite materials, which are mainly designed for aerospace and military applications. Yet, high cost and limited resources restrict its development to civil fields. As high performance steel is still the dominant structural material in twenty-first century, for examples, the high performance die &mould. It is of great interest to develop new type of iron matrix composites by the latest 3D printing technology. Song successfully fabricated Fe/SiC nanocomposites by adding a certain amount of hybrid nano-/micro-sized SiC particulates. The experimental results showed that the Fe/SiC nanocomposites exhibited much higher strength (753±49 MPa) [8], which have improved exponentially compared with pure iron samples (357± 22 MPa) [17]. AlMangour
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.msea.2017.09.092 Received 6 July 2017; Received in revised form 18 September 2017; Accepted 20 September 2017
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: bosong@hust.edu.cn (B. Song).
Materials Science & Engineering A 707 (2017) 478–487
Available online 21 September 2017 0921-5093/ © 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
MARK
et al. added hard TiC [13] and TiB2 [16] to the ferrous alloy to improve the microstructure and mechanical properties respectively, and found that whether adding TiB2 or TiC into the 316 L matrix, the optimum wear rate and coefficients of friction of the SLM-processed nanocomposites showed a sharp decrease compared with the unreinforced 316 L parts. These studies indicated that SiC, TiC and TiB2 could be used as suitable reinforcing phases to form iron based nanocomposites with improved mechanical properties. Nevertheless, there is no literature on the preparation of chromium carbide reinforced iron based nanocomposites by SLM. As a strengthening phase, Cr3C2, provided with both high hardness and good wear resistance, can effectively improve the hardness and wear resistance of the iron matrix, thus making up for the lack in these properties. In addition, the relatively low melting point of Cr3C2 results in a full metallurgical reaction between Cr3C2 and Fe matrix. Combined with the characteristic of rapid solidification of SLM technique, it can remarkably better the uniform distribution of alloy elements. Furthermore, Cr3C2 has a density of 6.68 g/ cm3 and coefficient of thermal expansion of 10.3 × 10−6/°C, both close to that of Fe powder (7.78 g/cm3 and 12.2 × 10−6/°C respectively). The small difference of physicochemical properties between them is helpful for the improvement of wettability and structure uniformity of the composite system [18,19]. Therefore, development of Cr3C2 particulate reinforced iron matrix nanocomposites is of great interest.
In the present work, Cr3C2/Fe matrix composites were produced by SLM starting from mechanically mixed Fe/nano-scaled Cr3C2 powders. This study mainly concentrates on the influence of secondary phases and processing parameters on the densification behavior, microstructural evolution and mechanical properties of the as-SLMed parts. The relationship can be established among process-microstructureproperties, which can provide a reference for fabricating iron-based composites with desired microstructure and performance in the future.

sections.heading: 2.1. SLM process
sections.text:
In this work, a commercial SLM machine, equipped with a single 400 W IPG fiber laser (SLM 125HL, SLM Solutions Group), was employed to fabricate the Cr3C2/Fe composites square blocks and tensile specimens on the stainless steel substrate. The diameter of operational beam is 100 µm. Before SLM process, the working chamber was vacuumed at first and then filled with argon in order to prevent the occurrence of oxidation during the SLM processing. Afterwards, the substrate was preheated to 180 °C, so that the residual stress can be reduced and the cracks in the parts can be prevented.
Fig. 1 shows the bulk iron matrix composites formed by 12 different sets of processing parameters. Other processing parameters are fixed: the hatch spacing (S), 120 µm; the layer thickness (H), 50 µm; a zigzag pattern scanning strategy of 67 degrees rotation between the adjacent layers were used. The samples were numbered from 1 to 12 according to the different forming parameters. It can be observed that the upper surfaces of the sample 4, 7, 10 are concave, indicating that over-melting occurred during the SLM process. In addition, the surface quality of sample 1, 2 and 3 appears to be better than the others.
On the basis of some preliminary experiments, the laser power was determined to be 200 W. Other parameters remain unchanged. And the influence of volumetric energy density (E) on the density behavior, hardness and tensile properties of SLM-processed Cr3C2/Fe parts were investigated by adopting three different scanning speeds: 600 mm/s, 900 mm/s and 1200 mm/s. E is determined by the following formula [20,21]:
=E P vSH (1)
Thus, square blocks with dimension of 10 mm × 10 mm × 5 mm and tensile specimens were produced at three different volumetric
energy density of 55, 37, 27 J/mm3. The tensile specimen were fabricated according to the CAD pattern in Fig. 2. For convenience, the samples were denoted by S1, S2, S3, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization
sections.text:
The particle size of Fe powder and Cr3C2 powder was measured by a laser particle size analyzer (Mastersizer 3000, Worcestershire, United Kingdom). The morphology of the pure iron and milled powders was observed by a Quanta Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FEI, Holland).
The SLM-fabricated Cr3C2/Fe parts were cut off from the substrate using a wire-cutting machine and then cleaned ultrasonically in acetone solution. The grinding and polishing were conducted on an automatic lapping machine. Using the image-j software, the values of porosity could be calculated from the pictures obtained by an optical microscope (OM) at the random position on the surface. Seven porosity measurements were conducted for each sample. The average values of porosity were taken after the maximum and minimum were removed. Before microstructure characterization, the samples were etched with 4% Nital reagent for 15 s. XRD measurements were performed on a XRD-7000S (Shimadzu, Japan) with the diffraction angle (2θ) varying from 20° to 90° at a scan rate of 10°/min. Additionally, transmission electron microscope (TEM) was also used to investigate the microstructure of the Cr3C2/Fe samples.
The tensile strength of the as-SLMed specimens was measured on an
electronic universal testing machine (Zwick/RoellZ010, Germany) with a cross head velocity of 1 mm/min at room temperature. The tensile direction in the tensile tests was perpendicular to the building direction. Three samples were analyzed for each processing parameter. The Vickers hardness measurements were performed on a 430SVD hardness test machine (Wilson Hardness, America) with a load of 1 kg and a loading time of 15 s. Seven hardness measurements were conducted for each sample. The average values of hardness were taken after the maximum and minimum were removed.

sections.heading: 3.1. Powder characteristics
sections.text:
Fig. 3a and b show the typical morphology and particle size distribution of Fe and Cr3C2 powder. The Fe powder is almost spherical in shape while the nano Cr3C2 powder exhibits an irregular shape and agglomeration. Pure iron powder with an average particle size of 29.7 µm and nano-scaled Cr3C2 powder with an average particle size of 131 nm were used as matrix metal and reinforcement, respectively. Before selective laser melting, the iron powders with 2.5 vol% Cr3C2 addition were mixed in a ball mill for 2 h under the protection of argon gas. The ball-to-powder ratio was 5:1 and rotation speed was set to 150 rpm. The purpose of the ball milling process is to make the Cr3C2 powder evenly dispersed in the iron matrix powder and then it can improve the metallurgical properties of the composite powders.
Fig. 3c shows the morphology of the milled powders. The milled
powders retained the initial spherical shape and the average size increased slightly. Furthermore, no clusters of nano Cr3C2 particles were observed in the composite powders as shown in Fig. 3d. Consequently, it can be concluded that the ball milling technique can evenly mix two or more kinds of powders and maintain the good fluidity of initial powder as well.
3.2. Densification behavior
Fig. 4 depicts the OM micrographs of the polished surface and the variation tendency of porosity level for the as-SLMed Cr3C2/Fe samples processed by different volumetric energy densities. It can be clearly seen that the volumetric energy density has a great influence on the densification behavior of the samples. When using a higher volumetric energy density of 55 J/mm3, a relatively dense surface can be obtained only with a small amount of spherical pores, less than 100 µm, scattered on the surface (Fig. 4a). And the corresponding calculated value of porosity level is 3.98%. When the E is reduced to 37 J/mm3, some irregular pores, more than 200 µm in length，arise in addition to some spherical pores (Fig. 4b), which giving a rise to the porosity level (9.99%). Further decreasing E to 27 J/mm3, the irregular pores show an increase in size and number, causing the porosity level up to 13.74%. Although the pores with different sizes existing in the SLM-processed parts, there are no obvious cracks, confirming that preheating the substrate helps to reduce the residual stress. The formation of spherical pores can be ascribed to the following reasons: (i) pores in the initial powder particles. When the particle was melted, the gas would be
released from inside; (ii) retained gas on the surface of the powders; (iii) gas induced by the evaporation of molten metal and metallurgical reaction. If the gas is not completely excluded from molten pool before solidification, spherical pores will be produced. While the formation of irregular pores is due to the lack of E. The lower the laser energy density, the shorter the cooling time of the molten pool, which results in the incomplete filling of voids emerging during the solidification process [22,23]. Another reason could also account for the presence of irregular holes: When a lower volumetric energy density was adopted, the width of the melting track also shortened, thus leading to the insufficient overlapping between adjacent melting tracks.
3.3. Phase identification
In order to investigate the phase constituent of the as-fabricated composite parts, XRD test were performed. Fig. 5a shows the typical XRD patterns of the Fe powders and Cr3C2/Fe parts. It can be concluded that two kinds of phases, namely M(Fe, Cr)23C6, (α-Fe, Cr) solid solution, are present in the Cr3C2/Fe parts. However, the Cr3C2 phase was not detected in the XRD results, which illustrates that the Cr3C2 reinforcement decomposed completely under the radiation of high laser energy. It is reasonable to have this phenomenon because the decomposition temperature of Cr3C2 phase is only 1800 °C, while the maximum temperature can reach above 3000 °C during the SLM process [24].
By amplifying the 110 peak, it can be clearly seen that 110 peak become broadened and moves lightly to the left compared with that of the Fe powders. The broadening of the 110 peak may be associated with the grain refinement, which will be displayed in the following sections. In addition, the shift of the 110 peak can be explained according to the Bragg equation:
=d θ nλ2 sinhkl (2)
During the metallurgical reaction process, Cr elements, derived from the decomposition of the added Cr3C2, can be dissolved into the Fe matrix, thus leading to the formation of (α-Fe, Cr) solid solution. In the light of the fact that the atomic radius of the Cr element is larger than that of the Fe element, when the Fe atom is replaced by the Cr atom, the lattice parameters will increase a bit subsequently. Since dhkl is proportional to the lattice parameters, a greater dhkl can be obtained. Based on the formula (2), when dhkl increases, θ will decrease. Therefore, the formation of (α-Fe, Cr) solid solution is responsible for the shift of 110 peak.

sections.heading: 3.4. Microstructure
sections.text:
Fig. 5a, c and e respectively show the morphologies of a single molten pool under different E. The yellow dashed lines represent the molten pool boundary. From the calculated half width W/2 of molten pool, it is evident that the values of W/2 under different E exhibit a decreasing tendency when reducing E. Similar results were found in other literature [25]. When a higher E was applied, the composites powders were more fully melted and more powders were involved in the melting process as well. Consequently, it makes sense that a higher E will give an increase to the dimension of molten pool.
High-magnification SEM images of Fig. 6a, c and e, shown in Fig. 6b, d and f, respectively, it revealed the morphology of solidified structure at the center of molten pool under different E. In Fig. 6b, the microstructure of S1 (E = 55 J/mm3) demonstrated that the columnar dendrites and equiaxed grains coexist in the matrix. The sizes of some equiaxed grains and dendritic crystals in S1, S2 and S3 were marked in Fig. 6. In the wake of reduction of the E, the crystal morphology pattern also had changed from columnar dendrite to equiaxed grain. As can be seen from Fig. 6f, the solidification microstructure of S3 (E = 27 J/ mm3) is mainly composed of equiaxed grains. When in the role of a higher E, the temperature at the center of the molten pool would reach
a higher value, which leads to an increase in the temperature gradient G and a decrease in the crystallization rate R. According to the criterion formula of constitutional supercooling:
< −G R m C K D K (1 )L L 0 0 0 (3)
where mL is the absolute value of liquidus slope, DL is the diffusion coefficient of solute in the liquid phase, C0 is the original alloy composition and K0 is the partition coefficient of solute in the solid-liquid phase. With a gradual increase in the degree of constitutional supercooling, the morphology of grains will progress successively from planar crystal to cell crystal, columnar dendrites and equiaxed crystal. In the material system with same composition, the degree of constitutional supercooling is mainly determined by the valve of G and R. For S1 (E = 55 J/mm3) fabricated at a higher energy density, the valve of G/R is relatively high, thus resulting in a relative low degree of constitutional supercooling at the center of molten pool and exhibiting a hybrid growth pattern (columnar dendrite and equiaxed grain). When the E is reduced to 37 J/mm3, the degree of constitutional supercooling will increase somewhat, giving rise to a reduction in the area of columnar dendrite. Further decreasing volumetric energy density to 27 J/ mm3, the degree of constitutional supercooling will further increase, with the result that massive growth of equiaxed grains would occur at the center of molten pool. This is roughly consistent with SEM observations.
Fig. 7 shows the chemical composition in different regions of S1. By comparing the two pictures, it can be concluded that the no obvious segregation occurred for Fe, C and Cr elements. This uniform elements distribution can be attributed to the rapid solidification and strong convection of molten metal. Transient solidification time can effectively limit the segregation of the constitutional elements and sufficient flow of molten pool can promote the uniform element distribution. It is generally accepted that the evenly distributed elements are beneficial to obtain parts with homogeneous performance. More interestingly, it is also found that the content of C element in the network-like structure is marginally higher than that in the matrix. In addition, C element mainly exist in the precipitate, which means that the network-like structure contain more carbides. It signifies that the network-like possesses higher hardness but lower strength. Similar results could be found in publication [26]. Thus, it is clear that this structure is detrimental to the strength of the composite material in the form of a continuous web as shown in the Fig. 6f, which will weaken the dispersion strengthening effect of carbides. With the increase of E, the continuous mesh structure in some regions will break as shown in the Fig. 6b and d. It is considered that the formation of non-network-like structure helps to enhance the strength of Cr3C2/Fe composites.

sections.heading: 3.5. TEM characterization
sections.text: Fig. 8 illustrates the TEM images of the SLM-fabricated Cr3C2/Fe composites as well as the corresponding selected area diffraction pattern (SADP). In the bright-field image of S1 shown in Fig. 8a, a large amount of precipitated carbides are found dispersed in a continuous or discontinuous manner throughout the matrix. The carbides scattered in a discontinuous manner can be divided into two types according to their sizes: fine carbides and coarse carbides, marked by blue arrows and red arrows respectively. These carbides can serve as powerful barriers to the dislocation movement and grain growth. The illustration in Fig. 8a shows the elemental composition of the carbides marked by the yellow circle, which is similar to that of M(Fe, Cr)23C6. The Si element may be introduced into the carbide as a result of grinding. By means of the magnification of coarse carbides depicted in Fig. 8b, it can be observed that a good interfacial bonding was formed between the matrix grains and the carbides. Moreover, a few of fine solid solution grains (tens of nanometers) can be found attached to the carbides. Fig. 8c illustrates the SADP corresponding to Fig. 8b. Polycrystalline diffractive rings reveal the different crystal planes of (α-Fe, Cr) solid solution and M23C6 phases. They all confirm the presence of the precipitated M(Fe, Cr)23C6 carbides and submicron-sized (α-Fe, Cr) solid solution grains, which are consistent with the results of XRD analysis. Fig. 8d shows the high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) of (α-Fe, Cr) solid solution and M23C6 phases in the yellow circle of Fig. 8b. The lattice fringe spacing of 0.2025 nm and 0.2132 nm are recognized as the (110) plane of (α-Fe, Cr) solid solution and the (422) plane of M23C6. In line with the calculated lattice parameters (Fig. 8d) and standard XRD patterns, it can be concluded that M23C6 phases simultaneously precipitate within the (α-Fe, Cr) solid solution matrix. By careful observation, it can also be found that a very thin interfacial layer formed between the two phases. It is generally accepted that the existence of an interfacial layer can improve the bonding strength of the matrix grains and the carbides, thus leading to an increase in the mechanical properties of the Cr3C2/Fe nanocomposites. In Fig. 8e and f, the carbides precipitated on the grain boundaries and carbides from tens of nanometers to hundreds of nanometers in the matrix can be observed.

sections.heading: 3.6. Hardness
sections.text:
The microhardness of the as-SLMed composite parts fabricated by different E was revealed in Fig. 9. The mean hardness of the SLMed Cr3C2/Fe composites was 452±18, 509±11, 479±12 HV, respectively when decreasing E from 57 to 27 J/mm3. The composites yield much higher hardness compared with that of as-SLMed pure iron parts
(below 160 HV) [27] and as-SLMed 2.5 vol% TiC/316 L composites (about 300 HV) as well [13]. It shows quite clearly that the addition of a small amount of Cr3C2 ceramic particles can greatly improve the hardness of composites. This high hardness mainly boils down to the dispersed precipitation of a large number of carbides and the formation of the (α-Fe, Cr) solid solution. To the best of our knowledge, M23C6 is a kind of hard phase with hardness as high as 1650 HV so that it has a great contribution to the improvement of the hardness of the composites. Besides, due to the difference in the atom size of Fe and Cr, the formation of substitution solid solution is bound to bring about lattice distortion in the local region of Cr atom, which also plays an important
role in hardening of the composites. As the microhardness measurement was carried out on the surface without pores, that is to say, the composite parts had a high hardness on the area with good metallurgical bonding. Therefore, further decrease in the porosity level of fabricated parts is necessary in the interest of improving the uniformity of performance.

sections.heading: 3.7. Tensile behavior
sections.text:
The Cr3C2/Fe tensile specimens illustrated in Fig. 10 were used for the tests and then the tensile stress-strain curves of specimens under
different E were obtained. It can be roughly drawn that the E has a certain influence on the tensile properties of Cr3C2/Fe composites, especially in the aspect of tensile strength. As depicted in Fig. 10, before
the stress run up to 200 MPa, the tensile stress-strain curves of the three groups are almost consistent with each other. After this, the S3 (E = 27 J/mm3) begins to undergo plastic deformation until the fracture
failure with an ultimate tensile strength of 546 MPa and an elongation of 0.91%. Based on the preliminary analysis of the results, it is considered that the porosity level of the samples is one of the reasons leading to this low tensile strength and elongation. Since the porosity of the S3 is up to 13.74%, great stress concentration will arise near the holes in the process of stretching, making it easier to form micro cracks. The existence of numerous micro cracks will speed up the fracture of the samples. There is no obvious difference in the tensile stress-strain curves of S1 (E = 55 J/mm3) and S2 (E = 37 J/mm3) before the fracture failure of S2. By contrast with S3, S2 exhibits a near double increase in the ultimate tensile strength (968 MPa) and a slight increase in the elongation (1.04%). This may be related to the decrease in the number of irregular pores, thus alleviating the stress concentration. In view of the lowest porosity of S1, so it has the highest ultimate tensile strength and elongation, respectively as 1158 MPa and 2.08%.
In order to make further efforts to analyze the fracture mode of the as-built specimens, SEM characterization was carried out to observe the fracture surfaces, as illustrated in Fig. 11. From Fig. 11a, c and e, it can be clearly seen that all fracture surfaces present steady river-like patterns composed of rugged cleavage steps. It was also noticed that these breaks generally originate in the internal pores of the samples and expand in a fan-shaped fashion, as demonstrated by the yellow arrows in Fig. 11a and e. Brittle fracture characteristics have been fairly reflected in these samples.
Furthermore, the fracture surfaces at high magnification reveal the coexistence of intergranular fracture and transgranular fracture (Fig. 11b, d and f). However, the dominant fracture mode seems to be distinct in the samples with different E. At a higher E of 55 J/mm3, the tensile fracture surface displays predominantly transgranular fracture
accompanied with a small area of intergranular fracture, as marked by the yellow arrows in Fig. 11b. When E decreased to 37 J/mm3, the area of the transgranular fracture is reduced to a certain extent while the intergranular fracture is enhanced somewhat (Fig. 11d). Continuing to lower E to 27 J/mm3, intergranular fracture becomes the foremost fracture mode instead of transgranular fracture. Evidently, an increase in E results in a transgranular fracture mode in the composites. When a higher E was employed, the average temperature of the molten pool was higher, and the convection of molten metal was stronger as well. Adequate convection helps to get homogeneous microstructure after solidification. Therefore, it can be roughly deduced that S1 (E = 55 J/ mm3) possesses a more homogeneous microstructure than S2 (E = 37 J/mm3), while S2 is superior to S3. A more homogenous microstructure contributes to improve grain boundary behavior and increase grain boundary strength accordingly. It may therefore be concluded that the change in the grain boundary strength should be responsible for the change in fracture mode, leading to the enhanced tensile strength and elongation. Similar conclusions were reported in other literatures [28,29]. As previously mentioned, the hard phase M23C6 is precipitated in the grains of plastic matrix phase. These fine dispersed and brittle particulates have an interaction with the dislocation, which hinders the movement of the dislocation, so that the grains have higher strength than that of the grain boundaries [30,31]. On the basis of this fact, the tensile specimen with predominantly transgranular fracture mode have a significant increase in the ultimate tensile strength and a modest increase in the elongation.
In brief, among the composites reinforced with nano Cr3C2 particles, S1 (E = 55 J/mm3) possesses a favorable comprehensive performance. In terms of hardness and tensile properties, the optimal values of Cr3C2/ Fe nanocomposites are superior to that of pure iron parts processed by SLM [32]. The marked increase in the strength and hardness for the Cr3C2/Fe nanocomposites was interpreted by the following strengthening mechanisms:
i) The precipitation enhancement by the M(Fe, Cr)23C6 phase. The carbides precipitated on the grain boundaries not only hinders the sliding and diffusion along the grain boundary, which reduces the nucleation and growth rate of the crack and cavity, but also limits the growth of the matrix grains and refine the grains. Intragranular precipitated carbides have been shown to activate the particlebridging mechanism, one of the reasons for producing the very high fracture strength of the Cr3C2/Fe nanocomposites.
ii) Strengthening of grain refinement. The fine grains, which result from the rapid solidification and precipitation of carbides, can merge along the shear direction, thus inducing a larger motion path of the dislocation. It is also assumed to be responsible for some improvement in the tensile strength.
iii) Solid solution strengthening of Cr element. In virtue of the difference in the atom size of Fe and Cr, the solute atoms Cr are able to bring about lattice distortion that would increase the resistance of the dislocation movement, thus improving the mechanical properties.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this study, Cr3C2/Fe nanocomposites with excellent tensile properties and hardness were fabricated by SLM from a mixture of powders. The main results and findings are drawn as follow:
(1) In a certain range, with an increase in E, the relative density of the Cr3C2/Fe nanocomposites increased consequently. (2) The values of molten pool under different E exhibit a decreasing tendency when reducing the E. In the wake of reduction in the E, the crystal morphology pattern changed from columnar dendrite to equiaxed grain growth. (3) The Cr3C2 reinforcements decomposed completely under the
radiation of high laser energy. The existence of the precipitated M (Fe, Cr)23C6 carbides and submicron-sized (α-Fe, Cr) solid solution grains were found in the microstructure. (4) After the addition of Cr3C2 reinforced particulates, the average hardness of the Cr3C2/Fe nanocomposites increased by a large margin. And what's more, the ultimate tensile strength can reach up to 1158 MPa for samples fabricated by the E of 55 J/mm3.

metadata.abstractText: This paper presents a study on the formation, microstructure and mechanical property of Cr3C2/Fe nanocomposites using selective laser melting (SLM). Scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscope (TEM) and tensile tests were conducted to investigate the influence of Cr3C2 particulates on the microstructure and mechanical properties. It was found that the porosity decreased when volumetric energy density increased from 27 to 37 J/mm, then rose to 55 J/mm. The results showed that the Cr3C2 particulates decomposed completely during SLM process and interacted with Fe matrix to form (α-Fe, Cr) solid solution and M(Fe, Cr)23C6 carbides. In addition, due to the characteristic of rapid solidification, very fine grains were obtained throughout the composites. The tensile tests showed that the ultimate tensile strength could reach up to
